p: We observed a periodicity of the epidemics, the first spanning 11 years (1943–1953) and the other 17 years. (1955–1971). During both epidemics, the birth rate was at there highest supporting the proposition that demographic changes may have a role in infectious disease epidemiology.[ 44 45] The rate of susceptible recruitment has long been known to control the magnitude and frequency of epidemics of fully immunizing childhood diseases.[ 44 46] Although no single theory has proved satisfactory, three explanations have been advanced: pathogen appearance and disappearance, environmental changes, and host-behavior changes.
